The generous fish 
 Kholeka Mabeta 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Once upon a time there was a very rich
 man caled Mpunzi. He had a wife and
 one daughter caled Nosisa. Mpunzi
 
 wanted a son, but he and his wife could
 not have any more children. Mpunzi
 blamed his wife for not giving him a son.
 
 He bulied his wife and treated her like a
 child. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One day Mpunzi was very angry and he 
 
 hit his wife with a stick. She ran away 
 back to her family. She left with a sad 
 heart because Mpunzi did not let her 
 
 take Nosisa with her. Mpunzi bulied his 
 daughter in the same way he bulied his 
 
 wife. Nosisa lived a very sad life. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Mpunzi decided to mary another wife.
 He hoped that the new wife would give
 him a baby boy. 
 
 Nosisa’s life became even more dificult
 when her father maried again. Mpunzi
 scolded her al the time and made her
 
 serve the new wife. Nosisa worked like a
 slave. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Mpunzi was very proud of his catle. He used to sit outside his homestead
 
 and watch his catle grazing in the field. He felt very satisfied with his
 wealth. 
 
 
 Mpunzi’s many servants cleaned around the homestead, and loked after
 his goats, catle and shep. They milked the cows for fresh milk that Mpunzi
 
 sold to other vilagers. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Mpunzi loved his new wife very much. He
 
 treated her like a quen. She sat inside
 her hut al day and gave orders to Nosisa
 and the servants. Nosisa woke up early
 
 every day to make tea for her 
 stepmother. She cleaned her hut and
 coked for her, but her stepmother
 
 always complained that her fod was
 cold, her tea was weak, and her hut was
 
 not clean. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One day Mpunzi became very angry at Nosisa. He scolded 
 her and hit her with a stick. Nosisa ran of to the river where 
 
 she sat and cried the whole afternon. 
 Sudenly she heard a voice coming out of the river. She 
 loked up and saw a big fish. The voice was coming from 
 
 the fish. Nosisa was so shocked she almost ran away, but 
 the fish stoped her. “Please don’t run away my daughter, I 
 
 am your mother. I have changed myself into a fish so that 
 your father does not know it’s me.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “What is the mater?” asked the fish.
 Nosisa told the fish everything about her
 
 sad life. “Don’t wory my girl. I wil bring
 you fod every day,” said the fish. The
 fish gave fresh vegetables to Nosisa. She
 
 had a feast. When she loked up the fish
 was gone. That day Nosisa went home
 
 smiling. She would not have to go to bed
 without fod as usual. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Nosisa went to the river every day. In the morning she woke 
 
 up as usual and did her chores around the house. At miday, 
 she went to the river. She caled out every time, and every 
 time the fish would apear with delicious fod. Nosisa 
 
 became hapier and hapier. She could talk to the fish about 
 anything. She started to regain her health. Her skin was 
 
 glowing and she was a hapy child. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Nosisa visited the fish every day until her stepmother
 became suspicious. Nosisa had gained weight and she was
 
 glowing. “Something is going on at the river, I must find out
 what it is,” thought the stepmother. 
 
 
 One afternon she folowed Nosisa to the river. She saw
 Nosisa talking to the fish, and geting delicious fod.
 
 Nosisa’s secret was out. “I have to do something about this
 fish,” said the stepmother. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 In the evening, Mpunzi came back from the fields. He found 
 his new wife crying in her hut. “What is wrong my lovely 
 wife,” asked Mpunzi. 
 
 “I went to a traditional doctor,” said the wife. “He told me that 
 the only way for me to give you a son is to eat the bigest 
 fish that lives in this nearby river,” she said. “Wil you catch 
 
 the fish for me tonight?” pleaded the woman. 
 “I wil do anything for you my beautiful wife,” said Mpunzi. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Mpunzi set of to the river before it was to dark. He tok his
 servants to help him find the bigest fish in that river. They
 
 searched and searched and eventualy Mpunzi caught the
 bigest fish. He put it in a bag and went home with it. When
 he got to the house, there was a god hot fire ready to cok
 
 the fish. 
 “I wil make the best meal ever for us,” said the woman to
 
 Mpunzi. “You are the bravest and strongest man I know.”
 Mpunzi was very pleased with himself. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 That night Mpunzi and his wife went to bed hapy after their 
 
 delicious meal. They left the bones on the table for Nosisa to 
 clean in the morning. 
 When Nosisa brought cofe into their hut in the morning 
 
 they were stil sleping. “This is very strange,” she thought to 
 herself. “My father usualy wakes up very early in the 
 
 morning to go to the fields. I wonder why he is stil sleping.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “Anyway, now I can run to the river for a nice breakfast,” she
 thought. Nosisa ran to the river. When she got there she
 caled out to the fish, and she caled again and again. The
 
 fish never came. Nosisa started to cry. She did not know
 what had hapened to the fish. 
 While she was crying a bird came to sit next to her and told
 
 her what had hapened. She cried harder thinking that her
 mother had ben caught and eaten. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The bird told her to colect the fish bones from the table and 
 throw them back into the river. If she did that the fish would 
 come back to life. The bird also told her to let her father and 
 
 stepmother slep and wake them up only at miday. Nosisa 
 did as she was told. She ran back home and walked quietly 
 into her father’s hut. They were stil fast aslep. She tok the 
 
 bones, put them inside a bag and threw them back into the 
 river. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 15  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Nosisa ran back home and just before miday she woke her
 father and stepmother. She could hardly recognise them.
 
 They loked old and grey and frail. They were to old to
 scold her. They were to weak to hit her. They were to tired
 to lok after the homestead. 
 
 So, Nosisa tok over the homestead and her father’s wealth.
 She caled al the servants and told them what had
 
 hapened. They prepared a feast and there was peace at the
 homestead from that day on. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 16
